definition: To show approval by clapping or praising.
examples: The audience applauded at the end of the play.
We applauded her effort and teamwork.

definition: Skilful at achieving aims by indirect or clever methods; sly.
examples: The crafty fox slipped past the gate.
She used a crafty trick to solve the puzzle.

definition: To make something known; to reveal or uncover.
examples: The report disclosed several safety issues.
Please disclose any allergies on the form.

extra.memory_tip: Disclose = do the opposite of ‘close’—open it up.

definition: Dull and without colour; a dull grey-brown colour.
examples: The walls were painted a drab colour. (adjective)
Winter landscapes can look a bit drab. (adjective)

definition: To cry out or speak suddenly and loudly, often from surprise or excitement.
examples: “Wow!” she exclaimed as the fireworks burst.
He exclaimed that the water was freezing.

extra.memory_tip: Exclaim = add an exclamation mark to your voice.

definition: Extremely beautiful, delicate, or finely made; very sensitive.
examples: The jeweller showed us an exquisite necklace.
She has exquisite taste in music.

definition: To have a plan or purpose in mind.
examples: I intend to finish my homework tonight.
They intended the gift as a surprise.

extra.memory_tip: Intend = in your head, aimed at the end.

definition: To shout rude or mocking remarks; a rude or mocking remark.
examples: It’s unkind to jeer at mistakes. (verb)
A jeer rose from the back row. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Jeer sounds like ‘jeer!’—a sharp, rude sound.

definition: To look closely or with difficulty; a person of the same age or status.
examples: She peered through the fog at the sign. (verb)
Talk to a peer if you need help. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Peer = appear closer with your eyes.

definition: Forward or onward movement; improvement; to move forward or improve.
examples: We made good progress on the project. (noun)
The seedlings are progressing well. (verb)

definition: To make something pure or improve it by making small changes.
examples: They refined the design after testing.
Sugar is refined to remove impurities.

definition: A dishonest or unkind person; a villain.
examples: The scoundrel ran off with the coins.
Stories often have a hero and a scoundrel.

definition: Worried, uncomfortable, or not at ease.
examples: He felt uneasy in the dark corridor.
There was an uneasy silence in the room.

extra.memory_tip: Uneasy = not easy in your mind.

definition: Too proud of one’s looks or achievements; producing no result; useless.
examples: He was too vain to admit his mistake.
Their vain attempt failed in the end.

extra.memory_tip: Vain = vanity mirror or an empty effort.

definition: Success in a game, competition, or struggle.
examples: The team celebrated their victory.
Hard work led to a narrow victory.
